body:
This looks pretty good.  My comments are fairly minor.

---

Reviewed 1 of 1 files at r3.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 4 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---

*[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 165 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I2rHXgzlCAuL_tTKz:-L-I2rHXgzlCAuL_tTL-:by6uzm9) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L165)):*
> ```cpp
>   if (ep_state != new_ep_state) {
>     conn->ep_state = new_ep_state;
> ```

Nit: Please remove unnecessary blank lines within functions.

---

*[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 249 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I3jXJ2hmr-etndZVh:-L-I3jXJ2hmr-etndZVi:bbvvtq6) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L249)):*
> ```cpp
>   proxy_connection* conn = (proxy_connection*)arg;
>   if (error != GRPC_ERROR_NONE) {
>     // Report a read failure on the client endpoint. If there is no pending
> ```

It seems a bit messy to handle this here, because we're basically lying to `proxy_connection_failed()` by telling it that there was a server endpoint failure when there really wasn't any.  Instead, how about having `proxy_connection_failed()` directly check `server_is_writing` to decide whether or not to shut down the server endpoint when it sees a client endpoint failure?

---

*[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 287 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I47oYeKLPtRmzb95z:-L-I47oYeKLPtRmzb96-:brhumzt) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L287)):*
> ```cpp
>   proxy_connection* conn = (proxy_connection*)arg;
>   if (error != GRPC_ERROR_NONE) {
>     // Report a read failure on the server end point. If there is no pending
> ```

Same here.

---

*[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 494 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I2M5FCJS99J-4b6zA:-L-I2M5FCJS99J-4b6zB:b-v1ob2f) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L494)):*
> ```cpp
>   conn->proxy = proxy;
>   gpr_ref_init(&conn->refcount, 1);
>   conn->ep_state = 0;
> ```

Not necessary, since we allocate the struct via `gpr_zalloc()` a few lines above this.

---

Review status: 0 of 1 files reviewed at latest revision, 4 unresolved discussions. --- *[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 165 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I2rHXgzlCAuL_tTKz:-L-IFel14x4o10vV8fp0:bs7wumx) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L165)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Nit: Please remove unnecessary blank lines within functions.
Done. --- *[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 249 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I3jXJ2hmr-etndZVh:-L-IG9Wl4m9AspOn_yvM:b-bxxqqd) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L249)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
It seems a bit messy to handle this here, because we're basically lying to `proxy_connection_failed()` by telling it that there was a server endpoint failure when there really wasn't any. Instead, how about having `proxy_connection_failed()` directly check `server_is_writing` to decide whether or not to shut down the server endpoint when it sees a client endpoint failure?
Actually this is messy no matter where we do it. I felt it is better to keep `proxy_connection_failed` to be dumb. The callers just "report" client/server read/write endpoint failures to it. If it notices both read and write failures in a particular endpoint, it shuts it down. Also, `proxy_connection_failed` is also called by the other callbacks used during initial connection establishments - and any failure during that time must be considered a failure in both endpoints. So that requires another special-case in `proxy_connection_failed`. Considering this, it felt like its a (relatively) cleaner way to keep `proxy_connection_failed`'s logic simple --- *[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 287 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I47oYeKLPtRmzb95z:-L-IHRU_h1rrQEsgQ8TD:bpw9hr7) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L287)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Same here.
(See previous comment) --- *[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 494 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I2M5FCJS99J-4b6zA:-L-IG7zAb8Awqhjzv5o7:bb6un1j) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L494)):*

Not necessary, since we allocate the struct via `gpr_zalloc()` a few lines above this.
Done --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579)*

Reviewed 1 of 1 files at r4. Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 2 unresolved discussions. --- *[test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc, line 249 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579#-L-I3jXJ2hmr-etndZVh:-L-IPZESJqIsOSocVSp7:byyazxo) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/445c5664e0572daa7b07fdde0e4959f0deeb803f/test/core/end2end/fixtures/http_proxy_fixture.cc#L249)):*
Previously, sreecha (Sree Kuchibhotla) wrote…
Actually this is messy no matter where we do it. I felt it is better to keep `proxy_connection_failed` to be dumb. The callers just "report" client/server read/write endpoint failures to it. If it notices both read and write failures in a particular endpoint, it shuts it down. Also, `proxy_connection_failed` is also called by the other callbacks used during initial connection establishments - and any failure during that time must be considered a failure in both endpoints. So that requires another special-case in `proxy_connection_failed`. Considering this, it felt like its a (relatively) cleaner way to keep `proxy_connection_failed`'s logic simple
I can deal with this being messy, as long as the messiness is hidden behind an API with clear semantics. Right now, we don't have a clean API for `proxy_connection_failed()`: the function says that the caller should tell it the types of failure has occurred, but what we are actually giving it is a separate set of flags that tells it what to actually do, and the state controlling that decision is split between `proxy_connection_failed()` and its callers rather than being centralized in one place. Please see the following PR for my suggested approach: https://github.com/sreecha/grpc/pull/10 --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579)*

Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
I can deal with this being messy, as long as the messiness is hidden behind an API with clear semantics. Right now, we don't have a clean API for `proxy_connection_failed()`: the function says that the caller should tell it the types of failure has occurred, but what we are actually giving it is a separate set of flags that tells it what to actually do, and the state controlling that decision is split between `proxy_connection_failed()` and its callers rather than being centralized in one place. Please see the following PR for my suggested approach: https://github.com/sreecha/grpc/pull/10
Thanks for the PR. I see your point. I merged your commit and send the updated PR with your changes. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13579)*

Thanks for fixing this!
